**_Day  12: Start a “worry” journal._**

Anxiety is undoubtedly a destroyer of good sleep. It keeps your mind racing and doesn’t allow you to rest, physically or mentally.

📖 If you find yourself frequently dealing with anxiety or stress in the evening, consider writing in a worry journal. A worry journal allows you to dump all your anxious feelings onto the pages. 

🤔 It helps you express your feelings, and sometimes even discover solutions. The goal is to reduce your anxieties and hush those racing thoughts.

🗒️ This works for those random to-do lists you have floating around or even things you’re excited about. Flesh out, in your journal, what you’re feeling and why. Your brain will get a sense of completion for the fact that you’ve just written this down and it’ll give you an incredible amount of peace.

👋 After getting those anxieties off your chest, leave those worries in the journal. Those worries shouldn’t cross the threshold into your sleep sanctuary. 

Whatever is worrying you can wait until tomorrow. For now, you can’t handle it very efficiently without a well-rested brain.

_Journaling reflection:_
1️⃣ What thoughts keep you up at night?

_Task:_
2️⃣ Write out your lights out time and your evening routine.

_For Fun:_
😃 Post a gif that represents your brain at night in <#972604513255039047>.

{🤫 Secret code... PHOENIXFAM}

<@&1027308048236163232> Can you believe we're about to finish out THREE weeks?! I hope this challenge has been as helpful as it has been fun. Let's keep it going!

**The focus this week is on Quality Sleep.**

We're working on new ways to deliver this content to you. You'll now click the buttons below to answer the prompt associated with it and it will auto-populate into <#972604513255039047>. 😃 We'll be adding more fun stuff, too! 

Same prizes as last week! The more you win during the week, the more chances you have to win the big prize drawn on Sunday. Ready?! LFG...

**_Day 11: Combatting racing thoughts._**

Worries, racing thoughts, and anxiety can get you stuck in a big pile of negativity quicksand. It becomes hard to remove yourself from it and keeps you in a state of panic.

Next time you find yourself struggling with racing thoughts, try this visualization technique to quiet your mind:

- **Close your eyes** and let yourself visualize whatever comes to mind - not just words, but an actual image. Pay attention to all the details, explore it, allow yourself to wonder how it will change.
- **Let your mind focus** on it completely. Allow the visualization to become more clear, more detailed, and more sharp. Sink deeper into the trance created by this visualization.
- **Generate random items** from your racing thoughts and refocus them into something that helps you relax. For instance, visualize shooting those items into the air as if they shot from a cannon.
- **Continue this visualization technique** and fall deeper and deeper into the trance. Eventually, you should become relaxed enough to fall asleep.

_Reflecting on racing thoughts:_
1️⃣ How often does your mind keep you up at night and how do you handle it? 
_Task:_
2️⃣ Write out your lights out time and your evening routine.
_For Fun:_
😃 Post a gif that represents your brain at night in <#972604513255039047>

<@&1027308048236163232> We've just crushed TWO WEEKS of sleep together, ya'll! 😮 Looking forward to hearing how you've done this week at today's Phoenix Friday! 

\*\*The focus this week is on Creating a Valuable Sleep Routine.\*\*

Just joining us? Each week day, I post a new prompt centered around sleep. Submit responses in <#1025421246038552646> to be entered. You can choose to answer one or all of the prompts; you are entered into the raffle for each prompt you complete. Daily winners are entered in to a weekly drawing, chosen on Sunday. 

Weekly winner will get their choice of: 
🍽 Nice dinner for two. 
📚 Three free journals from our Web2 company (<https://habitnest.com/>) 
🛍 A $75 Amazon gift card 
🪶 A Phoenix NFT 


\*\*Day Ten: Improve your mornings\*\*

\*Use your evening routine to prep for a successful morning.\* 

There’s no better favor you can do for your future self than to prep in advance so that the day can flow more smoothly and with a lighter workload! Setting yourself up for success can be a powerful part of your evening routine, and it can help you go to sleep with less mental clutter. 

Set aside time in your evening routine (ideally at least 15-30 minutes) to do something that helps you prepare for tomorrow. 

\*Here are some prep ideas:\* 

🗒 Knock a couple of small to-do’s off your task list for tomorrow 
🧹 Tidy up around the house 
👟 Set out your outfit and shoes for tomorrow 
🥚 Prep your lunch and/or breakfast 
🔑 Gather up your wallet, keys, purse/bag, etc., to avoid spending time looking for them in the morning 

For other ideas that are more specific to your situation, ask yourself what usually holds you up or makes you feel stressed in the morning, and then ask yourself how you can prep tonight in order to make your morning go more smoothly. 

\*Morning Prep Reflection:\* 
1️⃣ How often do you find yourself scrambling in the morning? What can you take care of in the evening to make your morning go more smoothly? 

\*Task:\* 
2️⃣ Write out your routine for tonight and add one item that will help start your morning off well. 
3️⃣ How was last night’s routine? Did you do anything to invest in yourself?
